OwnerUser.AboutMe:
My primary research is in figurative language and discourse but I've also taught intro to general linguistics, basic phonology and language and education. I'm interested in bi-lingualism, social variation, anthropological linguistics and blog about all on MetaphorHacker.net.

I've also been involved in teaching foreign languages and teacher training. I've taught Czech to foreigners and co-written a grammar and textbook (see Czechly.com) and I've worked as a regional language specialist for the US Peace Corps. I've also been the academic director of a private TEFL teacher training school.

Body: I think there is a bit of confusion about the translatability of the IPA. The [i] in English is lengthened or not lengthened based on convention of transcription rather than because of a belief in some underlying difference in pronunciation. [i:] is the typical modern transcription and [i] is used as a compromise in some contexts (like -ity) where different speakers pronounce different vowels. As such I think the comparison between French and English should happen outside the traditional transcription and on particular uses. I don't know enough about French to offer an opinion but thought I'd caution against oversimplifying the English situation. See http://www.phon.ucl.ac.uk/home/wells/ipa-english-uni.htm
